requirements:
Basic To-Do List Website Requirements
User Interface:

Simple input field to add new tasks quickly.

List display area showing tasks clearly.

Checkboxes or toggles to mark tasks as completed.

Edit and delete options for existing tasks.

Responsive design for use on both desktop and mobile devices.

Task Management:

Ability to add, edit, and delete tasks.

Mark tasks as complete or incomplete.

Option to prioritize or categorize tasks.

Save tasks persistently (local storage or backend database).

User Experience:

Clear visual differentiation between completed and pending tasks.

Easy navigation and intuitive controls.

Option to reorder tasks by drag and drop or priority.

Technical Requirements:

Responsive front-end using HTML, CSS, and JavaScript.

Optional backend for user authentication and task storage (using database).

Cross-browser compatibility.

Performance optimized for fast load and smooth interactions.

functional_requirements.description: Users must be able to add new tasks to their to-do list.
acceptance_criteria: User can enter text into an input field and click an 'Add' button.
The new task appears in the task list.
The input field is cleared after adding a task.
The application prevents adding empty tasks.

functional_requirements.description: Users must be able to mark tasks as complete to track their progress.
acceptance_criteria: Each task in the list has a checkbox next to it.
Clicking the checkbox toggles the task's completion status.
Completed tasks are visually differentiated from pending tasks (e.g., with a strikethrough).

functional_requirements.description: Users must be able to remove tasks they no longer need.
acceptance_criteria: Clicking the 'Delete' button removes the task from the list.
A confirmation prompt may appear before deletion to prevent accidental removal.

functional_requirements.description: Users should be able to edit the description of existing tasks.
acceptance_criteria: Clicking the 'Edit' button allows the user to modify the task's text.
The updated task text is saved and displayed in the list.

functional_requirements.description: Tasks should be saved persistently so the user does not lose their data between sessions. This can be achieved using browser Local Storage for simplicity.
acceptance_criteria: Tasks are saved when the user closes or reloads the browser window.
Saved tasks are loaded automatically when the user reopens the application.

functional_requirements.description: The application must have a responsive design that works on both mobile and desktop devices.
acceptance_criteria: The application layout adjusts cleanly to fit various screen sizes, from mobile phones to desktops.
All functionality is accessible and usable on both small and large screens.

functional_requirements.description: Users should be able to reorder tasks to prioritize them.
acceptance_criteria: Users can drag and drop tasks to change their order in the list.
The new order of tasks is preserved.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application should load quickly and provide a smooth user experience without noticeable delays.
metrics: Initial page load time under 2 seconds.
UI interactions (add, delete, check) complete in under 200ms.

non_functional_requirements.description: The interface should be intuitive and easy to use for a general audience with minimal learning curve.
metrics: A new user can add, complete, and delete a task within 60 seconds without instructions.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application must function correctly on the latest versions of major web browsers.
metrics: Full functionality and consistent appearance on the latest two versions of Chrome, Firefox, Safari, and Edge.

non_functional_requirements.description: The application should be usable by people with disabilities, following basic accessibility standards.
metrics: Compliance with WCAG 2.1 Level A standards.

risks: Scope Creep: The project is simple, but there's a risk of adding un-planned features like user accounts or multi-list support, which would increase complexity and timeline.
Data Loss: Since the primary data store is Local Storage, users could lose all their tasks if they clear their browser cache.
Browser Compatibility: Minor visual or functional inconsistencies may arise between different web browsers, requiring specific CSS/JS fixes.
assumptions: The initial version will not require user authentication; tasks will be stored locally in the browser.
The application is intended for a single user, and data synchronization across multiple devices is not a requirement.
The target audience uses modern, evergreen web browsers; extensive support for legacy browsers is not in scope.
The user interface will be simple and functional, without the need for complex animations or custom graphics.
